column1: /// @dev Handles distributing XDEFI to NFTs that have locked up XDEFI for various durations of time.
constructor (address XDEFI_, string memory baseURI_, uint256 zeroDurationPointBase_) ERC721(""Locked XDEFI"", ""lXDEFI"") {
function setBaseURI(string memory baseURI_) external onlyOwner {
function setLockPeriods(uint256[] memory durations_, uint8[] memory multipliers) external onlyOwner {
function lock(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_) external noReenter returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
// Lock the XDEFI in the contract.
// Handle the lock position creation and get the tokenId of the locked position.
function lockWithPermit(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_, uint256 deadline_, uint8 v_, bytes32 r_, bytes32 s_) external noReenter returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
// Approve this contract for the amount, using the provided signature.
IEIP2612(XDEFI).permit(msg.sender, address(this), amount_, deadline_, v_, r_, s_)
// Lock the XDEFI in the contract.
// Handle the lock position creation and get the tokenId of the locked position.
function relock(uint256 tokenId_, uint256 lockAmount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_) external noReenter returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_, uint256 newTokenId_) {
// Handle the unlock and get the amount of XDEFI eligible to withdraw.
// Throw convenient error if trying to re-lock more than was unlocked. `amountUnlocked_ - lockAmount_` would have reverted below anyway.
// Handle the lock position creation and get the tokenId of the locked position.
// Send the excess XDEFI to the destination, if needed.
// NOTE: This needs to be done after updating `totalDepositedXDEFI` (which happens in `_unlock`) and transferring out.
function unlock(uint256 tokenId_, address destination_) external noReenter returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_) {
// Handle the unlock and get the amount of XDEFI eligible to withdraw.
// Send the the unlocked XDEFI to the destination.
// NOTE: This needs to be done after updating `totalDepositedXDEFI` (which happens in `_unlock`) and transferring out.
function withdrawableOf(uint256 tokenId_) public view returns (uint256 withdrawableXDEFI_) {
function relockBatch(uint256[] memory tokenIds_, uint256 lockAmount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_) external noReenter returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_, uint256 newTokenId_) {
// Handle the unlocks and get the amount of XDEFI eligible to withdraw.
// Throw convenient error if trying to re-lock more than was unlocked. `amountUnlocked_ - lockAmount_` would have reverted below anyway.
// Handle the lock position creation and get the tokenId of the locked position.
// Send the excess XDEFI to the destination, if needed.
// NOTE: This needs to be done after updating `totalDepositedXDEFI` (which happens in `_unlockBatch`) and transferring out.
function unlockBatch(uint256[] memory tokenIds_, address destination_) external noReenter returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_) {
// Handle the unlocks and get the amount of XDEFI eligible to withdraw.
// Send the the unlocked XDEFI to the destination.
// NOTE: This needs to be done after updating `totalDepositedXDEFI` (which happens in `_unlockBatch`) and transferring out.
function getPoints(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_) external view returns (uint256 points_) {
function merge(uint256[] memory tokenIds_, address destination_) external returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
// For each NFT, check that it belongs to the caller, burn it, and accumulate the points.
// Mine a new NFT to the destinations, based on the accumulated points.
function pointsOf(uint256 tokenId_) external view returns (uint256 points_) {
function tokenURI(uint256 tokenId_) public view override(IXDEFIDistribution, ERC721) returns (string memory tokenURI_) {
function _generateNewTokenId(uint256 points_) internal view returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
// Points is capped at 128 bits (max supply of XDEFI for 10 years locked), total supply of NFTs is capped at 128 bits.
function _getPoints(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_) internal view returns (uint256 points_) {
function _getPointsFromTokenId(uint256 tokenId_) internal pure returns (uint256 points_) {
function _lock(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_) internal returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
// Prevent locking 0 amount in order generate many score-less NFTs, even if it is inefficient, and such NFTs would be ignored.
// Get bonus multiplier and check that it is not zero (which validates the duration).
// Mint a locked staked position NFT to the destination.
function _toInt256Safe(uint256 x_) internal pure returns (int256 y_) {
function _toUint256Safe(int256 x_) internal pure returns (uint256 y_) {
function _unlock(address account_, uint256 tokenId_) internal returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_) {
// Check that the account is the position NFT owner.
// Check that enough time has elapsed in order to unlock.
// Get the withdrawable amount of XDEFI for the position.
function _unlockBatch(address account_, uint256[] memory tokenIds_) internal returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_) {
// Handle the unlock for each position and accumulate the unlocked amount.
function _withdrawableGiven(uint96 units_, uint88 depositedXDEFI_, int256 pointsCorrection_) internal view returns (uint256 withdrawableXDEFI_) {
}",3289,347,"[H-01] Malicious early user/attacker can malfunction the contract and even freeze users' funds in edge cases
In the current implementation, `_pointsPerUnit` can be changed in `updateDistribution()` which can be called by anyone.

A malicious early user can `lock()` with only `1 wei` of XDEFI and makes `_pointsPerUnit` to be very large, causing future users not to be able to `lock()` and/or `unlock()` anymore due to overflow in arithmetic related to `_pointsMultiplier`.
As a result, the contract can be malfunctioning and even freeze users' funds in edge cases.
[H-02] The reentrancy vulnerability in _safeMint can allow an attacker to steal all rewards
There is a reentrancy vulnerability in the `_safeMint` function
[M-01] `_safeMint` Will Fail Due To An Edge Case In Calculating `tokenId` Using The `_generateNewTokenId` Function

NFTs are used to represent unique positions referenced by the generated `tokenId`. The `tokenId` value contains the position's score in the upper 128 bits and the index wrt. the token supply in the lower 128 bits.

When positions are unlocked after expiring, the relevant position stored in the `positionOf` mapping is deleted, however, the NFT is not. The merge() function is used to combine points in unlocked NFTs, burning the underlying NFTs upon merging. As a result, _generateNewTokenId() may end up using the same totalSupply() value, causing _safeMint() to fail if the same amount_ and duration_ values are used.

This edge case only occurs if there is an overlap in the `points_` and `totalSupply() + 1` values used to generate tokenId. As a result, this may impact a user's overall experience while interacting with the XDEFI protocol, as some transactions may fail unexpectedly.",3,"pragma solidity =0.8.10

function lockWithPermit(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_, uint256 deadline_, uint8 v_, bytes32 r_, bytes32 s_) external noReenter returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
IEIP2612(XDEFI).permit(msg.sender, address(this), amount_, deadline_, v_, r_, s_)

function _lock(uint256 amount_, uint256 duration_, address destination_) internal returns (uint256 tokenId_) {
function _toInt256Safe(uint256 x_) internal pure returns (int256 y_) {

function _unlock(address account_, uint256 tokenId_) internal returns (uint256 amountUnlocked_) {

Let's analyze the contract carefully to identify potential vulnerabilities:
- There's a `noReenter` modifier that's used on critical functions like `lock`, `relock`, `unlock`, etc. This is good.
- The contract has an owner who can set lock periods and the base URI.
- There's a two-step ownership transfer process with `proposeOwnership` and `acceptOwnership`.
- The contract uses Solidity 0.8.10 which has built-in overflow/underflow protection.
- The `lockWithPermit` function could be susceptible to front-running, but this is a general risk with permit patterns and not a direct vulnerability.
- The contract uses `SafeERC20` for token transfers which is good.
- In `_lock` function, `uint96 units = uint96((amount_ * uint256(bonusMultiplier)) / uint256(100))

- The contract makes assumptions about integer conversions, like in `_toInt256Safe` and `_toUint256Safe`. There's an attempt to check for negative numbers, but there's a risk if the values are extremely large.
- The contract uses SafeERC20 for transfers, which is good.
- In `setBaseURI`, there's no check to ensure the baseURI is not empty.
- In `proposeOwnership`, there's no check to ensure the newOwner_ is not the zero address.
- The tokenIds are generated based on points and total supply, which could lead to conflicts or predictability.
11. In `_lock`, the amount is checked to be <= MAX_TOTAL_XDEFI_SUPPLY, but there's no check to ensure the total of all locked amounts doesn't exceed this value.

1. **Missing Zero Address Validation**: The `proposeOwnership` function does not validate that the `newOwner_` is not the zero address, which could result in permanently locking the contract ownership if the zero address is proposed and accepted.
2. **Precision Loss**: In the `_lock` function, the calculation `uint96 units = uint96((amount_ * uint256(bonusMultiplier)) / uint256(100))
column2: ` could lead to precision loss due to the division before conversion to uint96.

column1: 3. **Integer Overflow in TokenId Generation**: The `_generateNewTokenId` function shifts the points value left by 128 bits and adds a counter. If the points value is large enough, this could overflow the uint256 and result in unexpected tokenIds.
4. **Inadequate Input Validation**: The `setLockPeriods` function accepts durations up to 18250 days (about 50 years), but does not validate the corresponding multipliers for reasonableness.
5. **No Maximum Multiplier Check**: The `bonusMultiplier` is stored as uint8, but there's no upper limit enforced, potentially allowing for extreme reward multipliers.
6. **Possible Reentrancy in External Calls**: While the contract uses a `noReenter` modifier, the `merge` function lacks this protection despite making external calls and modifying state.
7. **Front-Running Vulnerability**: The `lockWithPermit` function can be susceptible to front-running, as is common with permit patterns.
8. **Unchecked Return Values**: In the `updateDistribution` function, if `_updateXDEFIBalance()` returns a negative value, it's converted to 0 without any warning or event emission.
9. **Lack of Input Validation in Batch Functions**: The `relockBatch` and `unlockBatch` functions don't validate that the input arrays don't contain duplicate tokenIds.
10. **Potential for Multiple Unlocks**: There's no check to prevent a token from being included in multiple unlock batch operations if transactions are submitted simultaneously.
11. **No Validation of Duration in Constructor**: The `zeroDurationPointBase_` parameter in the constructor is not validated for reasonableness.
12. **Missing Events**: Important state changes like updating the distribution (via `_updateXDEFIBalance`) don't always emit events, reducing transparency.

13. **Centralization Risk**: The owner has significant control over the contract parameters, including the ability to modify lock periods which could affect user rewards.","### **Analysis and Comparison**
#### **[H-01] Malicious early user/attacker can malfunction the contract and even freeze users' funds in edge cases**

The issue arises in the `updateDistribution()` function, where `_pointsPerUnit` can be manipulated by anyone. A malicious early user can lock a minimal amount (e.g., `1 wei`) of XDEFI, causing `_pointsPerUnit` to become excessively large. This can lead to arithmetic overflow in calculations involving `_pointsMultiplier`, preventing future users from locking or unlocking their funds. The contract could malfunction, and users' funds could be frozen in edge cases.
The response list does not address the specific issue of `_pointsPerUnit` manipulation or the potential for arithmetic overflow due to malicious early user actions.
**Incorrect**. The response list does not identify or address this vulnerability, which is a critical issue involving contract malfunction and fund freezing.
#### **[H-02] The reentrancy vulnerability in _safeMint can allow an attacker to steal all rewards**
The `_safeMint` function contains a reentrancy vulnerability. An attacker could exploit this to repeatedly call the function and steal all rewards.
Partially matches with **""Possible Reentrancy in External Calls""** in the response list, which mentions the `merge` function lacking reentrancy protection.

**Partially Correct**. The response list identifies reentrancy as a potential issue but does not specifically address the `_safeMint` function or the risk of reward theft. The focus on the `merge` function is relevant but incomplete.
#### **[M-01] `_safeMint` Will Fail Due To An Edge Case In Calculating `tokenId` Using The `_generateNewTokenId` Function**

The `_generateNewTokenId` function generates `tokenId` values based on points and total supply. When positions are unlocked and NFTs are burned, `_generateNewTokenId` may reuse the same `totalSupply()` value, causing `_safeMint` to fail if the same `amount_` and `duration_` values are used. This edge case could lead to unexpected transaction failures, impacting user experience.

Matches with **""Possible Issues with Token IDs""** in the response list, which mentions that token IDs are generated based on points and total supply, potentially leading to conflicts or predictability.
**Correct**. The response list accurately identifies the issue with token ID generation and the potential for conflicts, aligning with the reported edge case in `_safeMint`.
- **[M-01] `_safeMint` Will Fail Due To An Edge Case In Calculating `tokenId` Using The `_generateNewTokenId` Function**
- **[H-02] The reentrancy vulnerability in _safeMint can allow an attacker to steal all rewards**
- **[H-01] Malicious early user/attacker can malfunction the contract and even freeze users' funds in edge cases**

The response list covers some vulnerabilities but misses critical issues like the manipulation of `_pointsPerUnit` and the associated risks of contract malfunction and fund freezing. While it identifies reentrancy and token ID generation as potential concerns, it does not fully address the specific risks described in the issue report. Improvements are needed to ensure comprehensive coverage of all vulnerabilities.",1,1,1,13,"```
